records.name: .github/prompts/compose-song.prompt.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: .github/prompts/compose-song.prompt.md -->
---
description: Compose Song template
mode: agent
---

<!-- id: compose_song -->
<!-- keywords: compose, song, melody, music, sid -->

Goal: Create a simple, pleasant SID melody with expressive phrasing.
Guidelines:
- Use triangle or pulse wave with ADSR settings such as A=1–2, D=2–4, S=6–10, R=3–6.
- Vary note lengths and add phrase breathing so the song feels alive.
- C major motifs work well for quick demos.

Output:
- Provide either a BASIC music program or a SIDWAVE specification.
- Include tempo and approximate bar phrasing in the response.

records.name: .github/prompts/sprite-demo.prompt.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: .github/prompts/sprite-demo.prompt.md -->
---
description: Sprite demo template
mode: agent
---

<!-- id: sprite_demo -->
<!-- keywords: sprite, graphics, move -->

Goal: Demonstrate a moving sprite with basic controls.
Steps:
1. Retrieve a relevant reference via RAG.
2. Assemble a PRG that configures VIC-II registers and loops.
3. Run the program and verify the on-screen result.

records.name: doc/6502-instructions.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/6502-instructions.md#Preamble -->
# 6502 / 6510 Assembly Quick Reference

This condensed guide targets the Commodore 64's 6510 CPU (NMOS 6502 core with an I/O port). It surfaces the essentials the MCP server should remind the LLM about when the user requests "assembly", "machine code", or "fast" routines.

---

records.name: doc/6502-instructions.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/6502-instructions.md#Addressing Modes Cheat Sheet -->
## Addressing Modes Cheat Sheet
| Mode | Syntax | Bytes | Notes |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Accumulator | `OPC A` | 1 | Operates on `A`. Often written without the `A` token. |
| Immediate | `#value` | 2 | Literal byte. |
| Zeropage | `$LL` | 2 | Low-byte address (`$00LL`); fastest memory access. |
| Zeropage,X / Zeropage,Y | `$LL,X` | 2 | Wraps inside zeropage (no carry). `,Y` only on `LDX`, `STX`. |
| Absolute | `$HHLL` | 3 | Full 16-bit address. |
| Absolute,X / Absolute,Y | `$HHLL,X` | 3 | Adds index; +1 cycle on page cross. |
| Indirect | `(addr)` | 3 | Only on `JMP`. Hardware bug: vector at `$xxFF` wraps to `$xx00` (6510). |
| (Indirect,X) | `(zp,X)` | 2 | Pre-index pointer table in zeropage. |
| (Indirect),Y | `(zp),Y` | 2 | Post-index pointer (adds `Y` after reading pointer). |
| Relative | `label` | 2 | Branch target = `PC + signed offset` (`-128 .. +127`). |

records.name: doc/6502-instructions.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/6502-instructions.md#System Vectors -->
### System Vectors
- `$FFFA/B` NMI, `$FFFC/D` RESET, `$FFFE/F` IRQ/BRK.
- After RESET the CPU reads the vector at `$FFFC` and starts executing there (C64 KERNAL init).

records.name: doc/6502-instructions.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/6502-instructions.md#Illegal / Undocumented Opcodes (NMOS 6502) -->
## Illegal / Undocumented Opcodes (NMOS 6502)
- Many exist (e.g. `LAX`, `SAX`, `RRA`). They can be useful, but rely on NMOS-specific behavior and may break on CMOS 65C02/FPGA cores.
- C64 Ultimate's 6510 clone usually supports common stable combos (`LAX`, `SAX`, `RLA`, `RRA`, `SLO`, `SRE`, `DCP`, `ISC`). Avoid ultra-unstable forms (`ANE`, `LXA`, `SHA`).
- When sharing code, prefer documented opcodes unless cycle critical.

records.name: doc/context/bootstrap.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/context/bootstrap.md#Device & Services -->
## Device & Services

- MCP server controls Ultimate 64/C64 via REST: upload/run BASIC or ASM, screen/memory I/O, drives, SID music, audio analysis, local RAG.
- Key chips: VIC-II ($D000), SID ($D400), CIA1 ($DC00), CIA2 ($DD00).

records.name: doc/context/bootstrap.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/context/bootstrap.md#PETSCII, Screen & Colors -->
## PETSCII, Screen & Colors

- Screen at $0400 (40×25); write screen codes. Colour RAM at $D800 (nybbles). Border $D020, background $D021.
- To draw pixels: use bitmap mode and write to bitmap memory; control colours via attributes (screen/colour RAM in text, nybbles per cell in bitmap multicolour).

records.name: doc/context/bootstrap.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/context/bootstrap.md#6502/6510 Assembly – Condensed -->
## 6502/6510 Assembly – Condensed

- Addressing modes: `#imm, zp, zp,X, zp,Y, abs, abs,X, abs,Y, (zp), (zp,X), (zp),Y, rel`.
- Key opcodes (full set):
  - Load/Store: `LDA LDX LDY` / `STA STX STY`.
  - ALU: `ADC SBC AND ORA EOR ASL LSR ROL ROR`.
  - Inc/Dec: `INC INX INY DEC DEX DEY`.
  - Compare/Bit: `CMP CPX CPY BIT`.
  - Branch: `BCC BCS BEQ BMI BNE BPL BVC BVS`.
  - Jump/Call: `JMP JSR RTS RTI`.
  - Status: `CLC SEC CLI SEI CLD SED CLV NOP`.
  - Stack: `PHA PHP PLA PLP TAX TXA TAY TYA TSX TXS BRK`.
- Directives (assembler used here): `.org/*=`, `.byte`, `.word`, `.text/.ascii`, `ds` (fill), labels `name:`.
- Interrupts: set IRQ vector at $0314/$0315 to your routine; acknowledge VIC-II IRQ by writing back bit to $D019.
- Example (border flash): write to `$D020` inside raster IRQ (`$D012`/`$D011`), mask `$D01A`, acknowledge `$D019`.

records.name: doc/context/bootstrap.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/context/bootstrap.md#Image & Sprite Quick Start -->
## Image & Sprite Quick Start

- Bitmap (hi-res): set `$D011` bit 5=1, `$D016` bit 5=0; point `$D018` to screen/bitmap; write bits into bitmap memory.
- Multicolour bitmap: also set `$D016` bit 5=1; use `$D022–$D024` and colour RAM per cell.
- Sprites: define 63-byte patterns; set sprite pointers at $07F8–$07FF; position with `$D000–$D00F`, enable with `$D015`.

records.name: doc/sid-file-structure.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/sid-file-structure.md#Preamble -->
# SID File Structure (PSID/RSID) — Concise Overview

This guide summarizes the High Voltage SID Collection (HVSC) "PSID file format" header used by classic SID tunes. A SID file consists of:

- A header containing metadata and playback parameters
- The actual 6502 machine code and data that the player runs on the C64

You can play a SID file on a connected device using the REST API via the MCP tool `sidplay_file`.

records.name: doc/sid-file-structure.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/sid-file-structure.md#Quick start: play a SID via REST/MCP -->
## Quick start: play a SID via REST/MCP

- Endpoint: `POST /tools/sidplay_file`
- Body: `{ "path": "/flash/music/Example.sid", "songnr": 1 }` (optional `songnr`)

Refer to `doc/c64-rest-api.md` for the underlying device endpoint and options.

records.name: doc/sid-file-structure.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/sid-file-structure.md#Timing and interrupts -->
## Timing and interrupts

- `speed` determines whether playback uses VBlank (VIC raster IRQ) or CIA1 timer.
- In RSID, VIC raster is generally not to be assumed; rely on the player-installed timing per header hints.

records.name: doc/sid-file-structure.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/sid-file-structure.md#Related API and tools -->
## Related API and tools

- Play from device filesystem: `sidplay_file` (see generated `mcp-manifest.json` and `src/index.ts`)
- Low-level SID register programming: see `doc/sid-overview.md`

References for further reading: HVSC PSID v2NG file format (spec), community resources, and project notes from implementations like SIDman.

records.name: doc/sid-overview.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/sid-overview.md#Filter Block -->
## Filter Block
- **Cutoff:** $D415 + $D416 (11 bits).  
- **Resonance / Routing:** $D417.  
- **Mode / Volume:** $D418 → LP/BP/HP bits + master volume.  
- **Differences:** 6581 = nonlinear; 8580 = more accurate.

---

records.name: doc/sid-overview.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/sid-overview.md#Famous Effects -->
## Famous Effects
**Arpeggio** – Cycle chord intervals (e.g. 0,+4,+7) each tick by rewriting FREQ.  
**Vibrato** – Small sinusoidal offset of FREQ each tick (software LFO).  
**PWM** – Periodic variation of pulse-width for animated tone.  
**Filter Sweep** – Ramp cutoff ($D415/$D416) and/or resonance ($D417).  
**Hard Restart** – Clear GATE early, optionally TEST=1 to reset osc; next tick set ADSR + GATE=1 for tight attack.  
**Sync / Ring-Mod** – Enable SYNC or RING bits in CTRL to tie oscillators.  
**Digi Playback** – Rapid writes to $D418 volume simulate 4-bit PCM DAC (~4–8 kHz).

---

records.name: doc/sid-overview.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/sid-overview.md#Primary References (for RAG) -->
## Primary References (for RAG)
- Oxyron SID Register Reference — bit map, frequency formulas, play sequence.  
- Commodore 64 Programmer’s Reference (sound chapter, PDF).  
- C64-Wiki — SID overview and filter behavior.  
- Codebase64 — SID programming patterns (arpeggio, vibrato, PWM, players).  
- $D418 Digi Playback articles — technique and bias requirements.

---

records.name: doc/sid-programming-best-practices.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/sid-programming-best-practices.md#3. Proper ADSR Envelope -->
### 3. Proper ADSR Envelope

- **Attack/Decay (54277)**: `17` = fast attack (1), slow decay (7)
- **Sustain/Release (54278)**: `240` = high sustain (15), no release (0)
- **Effect**: Creates natural-sounding note onset and sustain

records.name: doc/sidwave.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/sidwave.md#Preamble -->
# SIDWAVE Format Specification

This document defines **SIDWAVE**, a declarative format for describing structured, modern C64 SID compositions.
SIDWAVE files are authored in YAML (optionally JSON) and compiled by an MCP server into `.SID` or `.PRG` binaries for playback on the Commodore 64 via the Ultimate64 REST API.

---

records.name: doc/sidwave.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/sidwave.md#Purpose -->
## Purpose

SIDWAVE provides a human- and machine-readable way to describe complex, atmospheric, and modern electronic music for the MOS 6581/8580 SID chip.
It captures instruments, modulation, and structure symbolically, allowing large language models to generate music that the MCP expands into precise SID register sequences.

Pipeline:

LLM → SIDWAVE (YAML) → MCP Compiler → SID Binary (.sid/.prg) → Ultimate64 REST → C64 Playback

---

records.name: doc/sidwave.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/sidwave.md#File and Schema Conventions -->
## File and Schema Conventions

- **Format name:** SIDWAVE
- **File suffix:** `.sidwave.yaml` (or `.sid.yaml` for brevity)
- **Schema field:** `sidwave: 1.0`
- **Schema file:** `sidwave.schema.json`
- **Primary serialization:** YAML 1.2 (JSON also valid)

---

records.name: doc/sidwave.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/sidwave.md#MCP Responsibilities -->
## MCP Responsibilities

1. Parse SIDWAVE YAML or JSON input.
2. Expand patterns, transpositions, and modulation into frame-accurate SID register writes.
3. Compile to valid `.SID` or `.PRG` binaries with proper init and play routines.
4. Send the binary to Ultimate64 via:

```
POST /v1/attachment:sid
Content-Type: application/octet-stream
Body = compiled binary
```

---

records.name: doc/sidwave.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/sidwave.md#Authoring and Validation -->
## Authoring and Validation

- SIDWAVE files are plain YAML and open cleanly in any standard editor.
- Validation uses JSON Schema:

```json
{
  "yaml.schemas": {
    "https://example.com/sidwave.schema.json": "*.sidwave.yaml"
  }
}
```

This enables autocomplete, hover info, and validation in VS Code or similar IDEs.

---

records.name: doc/sidwave.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/sidwave.md#LLM Prompt Template -->
## LLM Prompt Template

> Compose a 3–5 minute atmospheric, modern electronic SID composition using the **SIDWAVE** format.
> Use three voices with expressive modulation (PWM, filter sweeps, arpeggios, evolving pads).
> Output valid YAML conforming to `sidwave.schema.json`.
> Avoid direct note repetition; reuse and transpose patterns.

records.name: doc/troubleshooting-mcp.md
records.text:
<!-- Source: doc/troubleshooting-mcp.md#Should contain: -->
## Should contain:

```json
{
  "c64u": {
    "host": "c64u"
  }
}
```

**Or:**

```json
{
  "c64u": {
    "host": "192.168.1.13",
    "port": 80
  }
}
```

**Test C64 Connectivity:**

```bash
# Test Ultimate 64 REST API directly
curl -s http://192.168.1.13/v1/info
curl -s http://c64u/v1/info

# If both fail, check network/Ultimate 64 power
ping 192.168.1.13
```

records.name: github.com/cslarsen_c64-examples/constants.asm
records.text:
;; Start of BASIC program
basic = $0801

;; Background color
bgcol = $d021

;; Border color
bocol = $d020

records.name: github.com/kschuetz_c64-chip8/include/c64.inc
records.text:
COLOR_RAM = $d800
IRQ_VECTOR = $fffe

BLACK = 0
WHITE = 1
RED = 2
CYAN = 3
PURPLE = 4
GREEN = 5
BLUE = 6
YELLOW = 7
ORANGE = 8
BROWN = 9
LIGHT_RED = 10
DARK_GRAY = 11
MED_GRAY = 12
LIGHT_GREEN = 13
LIGHT_BLUE = 14
LIGHT_GRAY = 15

records.name: github.com/kschuetz_c64-chip8/source/vars.s
records.text:
.include "common.s"

.exportzp irq_zp0
.exportzp irq_zp1
.exportzp irq_zp2
.exportzp irq_zp3
.exportzp irq_zp4
.exportzp irq_zp5
.exportzp irq_zp6
.exportzp irq_zp7
.exportzp zp0
.exportzp zp1
.exportzp zp2
.exportzp zp3
.exportzp zp4
.exportzp zp5
.exportzp zp6
.exportzp zp7

.zeropage

;; zp0..7:  Temporary utility registers in zeropage.  Do not use in routines called by IRQ handlers.

zp0:        .res 1
zp1:        .res 1
zp2:        .res 1
zp3:        .res 1
zp4:        .res 1
zp5:        .res 1
zp6:        .res 1
zp7:        .res 1

;; irq_zp0..7:  Temporary utility registers in zeropage.  Only use in routines called by IRQ handlers.

irq_zp0:    .res 1
irq_zp1:    .res 1
irq_zp2:    .res 1
irq_zp3:    .res 1
irq_zp4:    .res 1
irq_zp5:    .res 1
irq_zp6:    .res 1
irq_zp7:    .res 1

records.name: sid-file-structure.md
records.text:
# SID File Structure Reference (for RAG)

See `doc/sid-file-structure.md` for the complete explanation of PSID/RSID headers, fields, and playback behavior. This stub ensures the RAG index includes this topic and can surface it when generating or playing songs.

- Magic: `PSID` or `RSID`
- Key fields: version, dataOffset, loadAddress, initAddress, playAddress, songs, startSong, speed
- v2–v4 extras: flags (PAL/NTSC, 6581/8580), startPage/pageLength, second/third SID base
- Song length lookup: HVSC `Songlengths.md5` by MD5 of full file
